docfields.name: deprecated
docfields.text: Deprecated List Member KCModule exportText const since 5.0 obsolete feature Member KCModule setExportText const QString since 5.0 obsolete feature Member KStandardAction stdName StandardAction act_enum use name()

docfields.name: KCModule
docfields.text: Configuration modules are realized as plugins that are loaded only when needed The module in principle is a simple widget displaying the item to be changed The module has a very small interface All the necessary glue logic and the GUI bells and whistles are provided by the control center and must not concern the module author To write a config module you have to create a library that contains a factory function like the following The constructor of the KCModule then looks like this If you want to make the KCModule available only conditionally i.e show in the list of available modules only if some test succeeds then you can use Hidden in the desktop file An example The example executes the given code in a shell and uses the stdout output for the Hidden value so it s either Hidden true or Hidden false See for more detailed documentation Matthias Hoelzer-Kluepfel

docfields.name: KCModule::Button
docfields.text: You should only use Help Default and Apply The rest is obsolete NoAdditionalButton can be used when we do not want have other button that Ok Cancel KCModule::buttons KCModule::setButtons

docfields.name: KCModule::changed
docfields.text: This signal is emitted whenever the state of the configuration shown in the module changes It allows the module container to keep track of unsaved changes

docfields.name: KCModule::quickHelpChanged
docfields.text: Emit this signal whenever the module s quickhelp changes Modules implemented as tabbed dialogs might want to implement per-tab quickhelp for example

docfields.name: KCModule::rootOnlyMessageChanged
docfields.text: Emits this signal whenever the module s root message changes 4.4

docfields.name: KCModule::defaults
docfields.text: This method is called when the user clicks the button It should set the display to useful values If you use KConfigXT you do not have to reimplement this function since the fetching and settings of default values is done automatically However if you reimplement and also are using KConfigXT remember to call the base function at the very end of your reimplementation

docfields.name: KCModule::load
docfields.text: The load method sets the user interface elements of the module to reflect the current settings stored in the configuration files This method is invoked whenever the module should read its configuration most of the times from a config file and update the user interface This happens when the user clicks the button in the control center to undo all of his changes and restore the currently valid settings It is also called right after construction

docfields.name: KCModule::save
docfields.text: The save method stores the config information as shown in the user interface in the config files If necessary this method also updates the running system e.g by restarting applications This normally does not apply for KSettings::Dialog modules where the updating is taken care of by KSettings::Dispatcher save is called when the user clicks or If you use KConfigXT saving is taken care off automatically and you do not need to load manually However if you for some reason reimplement it and also are using KConfigXT you must call this function otherwise the saving of KConfigXT options will not work Call it at the very end of your reimplementation to avoid changed() signals getting emitted when you modify widgets

docfields.name: KCModule::KCModule
docfields.text: do not emit changed signals here since they are not yet connected to any slot aboutData becomes owned by the KCModule

docfields.name: KCModule::KCModule
docfields.text: do not emit changed signals here since they are not yet connected to any slot

docfields.name: KCModule::aboutData
docfields.text: If you override you should have it return a pointer to a constant the KAboutData for this module

docfields.name: KCModule::authAction
docfields.text: By default its an invalid action The action that has to be authorized to execute the save() method

docfields.name: KCModule::buttons
docfields.text: The return value is a value or ed together from the Button enumeration type KCModule::setButtons

docfields.name: KCModule::configs
docfields.text: a list of KConfigDialogManager s in use if any

docfields.name: KCModule::exportText
docfields.text: since 5.0 obsolete feature

docfields.name: KCModule::needsAuthorization
docfields.text: By default it s false true if the module s save() method requires authorization false otherwise

docfields.name: KCModule::quickHelp
docfields.text: This method is called when the module is docked The quick-help text should contain a short description of the module and links to the module s help files You can use QML formatting tags in the text make sure the quick help text gets translated use i18n()

docfields.name: KCModule::rootOnlyMessage
docfields.text: When the module must be run as root or acts differently for root and a normal user it is sometimes useful to customize the message that appears at the top of the module when used as a normal user This function returns this customized message If none has been set a default message will be used KCModule::setRootOnlyMessage

docfields.name: KCModule::setAuthAction
docfields.text: It will still have to execute the action itself using the KAuth library so this method is not technically needed to perform the action but using this method will ensure that hosting applications like System Settings or kcmshell behave correctly action the action that will be used by this KCModule

docfields.name: KCModule::setExportText
docfields.text: since 5.0 obsolete feature

docfields.name: KCModule::setNeedsAuthorization
docfields.text: The module can set this property to true if it requires authorization It will still have to execute the action itself using the KAuth library so this method is not technically needed to perform the action but using this and/or the setAuthAction() method will ensure that hosting applications like System Settings or kcmshell behave correctly Called with true this method will set the action to where is aboutData() appName() return value This default action won t be set if the aboutData() object is not valid Note that called with false this method will reset the action name set with setAuthAction() needsAuth Tells if the module s save() method requires authorization to be executed

docfields.name: KCModule::useRootOnlyMessage
docfields.text: In some cases the module don t want a RootOnly message to appear for example if it has already one This function tells KControl if a RootOnly message should be shown KCModule::setUseRootOnlyMessage

docfields.name: KCModule::addConfig
docfields.text: This function is useful if you need to handle multiple configuration files a pointer to the KCoreConfigDialogManager in use config the KCoreConfigSkeleton to use widget the widget to watch

docfields.name: KCModule::addConfig
docfields.text: This function is useful if you need to handle multiple configuration files a pointer to the KConfigDialogManager in use config the KConfigSkeleton to use widget the widget to watch

docfields.name: KCModule::setButtons
docfields.text: Help shows a button Default shows a button Apply in kcontrol this will show an and button in kcmshell this will show an and button If Apply is not specified kcmshell will show a button KCModule::buttons

docfields.name: KCModule::setRootOnlyMessage
docfields.text: This message will be shown at the top of the module if useRootOnlyMessage is set If no message is set a default one will be used KCModule::rootOnlyMessage

docfields.name: KCModule::setUseRootOnlyMessage
docfields.text: Following the value of on the RootOnly message will be shown or not KCModule::useRootOnlyMessage

docfields.name: KCodecAction
docfields.text: This action shows up a submenu with a list of the available codecs on the system

docfields.name: KCodecAction::triggered
docfields.text: Note that triggered(const QString&) is emitted too as defined in KSelectAction

docfields.name: KCodecAction::triggered
docfields.text: emits KEncodingProber::Universal if Default was selected Applicable only if showAutoOptions in c tor was true

docfields.name: KCodecAction::currentProberType
docfields.text: KEncodingProber::None if specific encoding is selected not autodetection otherwise you know it!

docfields.name: KCodecAction::setCurrentProberType
docfields.text: KEncodingProber::Universal means Default item

docfields.name: KColorScheme
docfields.text: KColorScheme currently provides access to the system color palette that the user has selected in the future it is expected to do more It greatly expands on QPalette by providing five distinct with several color choices each covering background foreground and decoration colors A KColorScheme instance represents colors corresponding to a where a set consists of those colors used to draw a particular type of element such as a menu button view selected text or tooltip Each set has a distinct set of colors so you should always use the correct set for drawing and never assume that a particular foreground for one set is the same as the foreground for any other set Individual colors may be quickly referenced by creating an anonymous instance and invoking a lookup member The color palettes for the various states of a widget active inactive disabled may be wildly different Therefore it is important to take the state into account This is why the KColorScheme constructor requires a QPalette::ColorGroup as an argument To facilitate working with potentially-varying states two convenience API s are provided These are KColorScheme::adjustBackground and its sister KColorScheme::adjustForeground and the helper class KStatefulBrush KColorScheme::ColorSet KColorScheme::ForegroundRole KColorScheme::BackgroundRole KColorScheme::DecorationRole KColorScheme::ShadeRole

docfields.name: KColorScheme::BackgroundRole
docfields.text: Background colors are suitable for drawing under text and should never be used to draw text In combination with one of the overloads of KColorScheme::shade they may be used to generate colors for drawing frames bevels and similar decorations

docfields.name: KColorScheme::NormalBackground
docfields.text: Normal background

docfields.name: KColorScheme::AlternateBackground
docfields.text: Alternate background for example for use in lists This color may be the same as BackgroundNormal especially in sets other than View and Window

docfields.name: KColorScheme::ActiveBackground
docfields.text: Third color for example items which are new active requesting attention etc Alerting the user that a certain field must be filled out would be a good usage although NegativeBackground could be used to the same effect depending on what you are trying to achieve Unlike ActiveText this should not be used for mouseover effects

docfields.name: KColorScheme::LinkBackground
docfields.text: Fourth color corresponds to unvisited links Exactly what this might be used for is somewhat harder to qualify it might be used for bookmarks as a you can click here indicator or to highlight recent content i.e in a most-recently-accessed list

docfields.name: KColorScheme::VisitedBackground
docfields.text: Fifth color corresponds to visited links This can also be used to indicate content especially when a color is needed to denote content which is or

docfields.name: KColorScheme::NegativeBackground
docfields.text: Sixth color for example errors untrusted content etc

docfields.name: KColorScheme::NeutralBackground
docfields.text: Seventh color for example warnings secure/encrypted content

docfields.name: KColorScheme::PositiveBackground
docfields.text: Eigth color for example success messages trusted content

docfields.name: KColorScheme::ColorSet
docfields.text: Color sets define a color suitable for drawing all parts of a given region Colors from different sets should not be combined

docfields.name: KColorScheme::View
docfields.text: Views for example frames input fields etc If it contains things that can be selected it is probably a View

docfields.name: KColorScheme::Window
docfields.text: Non-editable window elements for example menus If it isn t a Button View or Tooltip it is probably a Window

docfields.name: KColorScheme::Button
docfields.text: Buttons and button-like controls In addition to buttons controls such as non-editable dropdowns scrollbar sliders slider handles etc should also use this role

docfields.name: KColorScheme::Selection
docfields.text: Selected items in views Note that unfocused or disabled selections should use the Window role This makes it more obvious to the user that the view containing the selection does not have input focus

docfields.name: KColorScheme::Tooltip
docfields.text: Tooltips The tooltip set can often be substituted for the view set when editing is not possible but the Window set is deemed inappropriate help is an excellent example another might be pop-up notifications depending on taste

docfields.name: KColorScheme::Complementary
docfields.text: Complementary areas Some applications want some areas to have a different color scheme Ususally dark areas over a light theme For instance the fullscreen UI of a picture viewer or the logout/lock screen of the plasma workspace ask for a dark color scheme even on light themes 5.19

docfields.name: KColorScheme::DecorationRole
docfields.text: Decoration colors are used to draw decorations such as frames for special purposes Like color shades they are neither foreground nor background colors Text should not be painted over a decoration color and decoration colors should not be used to draw text

docfields.name: KColorScheme::FocusColor
docfields.text: Color used to draw decorations for items which have input focus

docfields.name: KColorScheme::HoverColor
docfields.text: Color used to draw decorations for items which will be activated by clicking

docfields.name: KColorScheme::ForegroundRole
docfields.text: Foreground colors are suitable for drawing text or glyphs such as the symbols on window decoration buttons assuming a suitable background brush is used and should never be used to draw backgrounds For window decorations the following is suggested but not set in stone Maximize PositiveText Minimize NeutralText Close NegativeText WhatsThis LinkText Sticky ActiveText

docfields.name: KColorScheme::NormalText
docfields.text: Normal foreground

docfields.name: KColorScheme::InactiveText
docfields.text: Second color for example comments items which are old inactive or disabled Generally used for things that are meant to be InactiveText is not the same role as NormalText in the inactive state

docfields.name: KColorScheme::ActiveText
docfields.text: Third color for example items which are new active requesting attention etc May be used as a hover color for clickable items

docfields.name: KColorScheme::LinkText
docfields.text: Fourth color use for unvisited links May also be used for other clickable items or content that indicates relationships items that indicate somewhere the user can visit etc

docfields.name: KColorScheme::VisitedText
docfields.text: Fifth color used for visited links As with LinkText may be used for items that have already been or accessed May also be used to indicate i.e items or information especially if InactiveText is being used in the same context to express something different

docfields.name: KColorScheme::NegativeText
docfields.text: Sixth color for example errors untrusted content deletions etc

docfields.name: KColorScheme::NeutralText
docfields.text: Seventh color for example warnings secure/encrypted content

docfields.name: KColorScheme::PositiveText
docfields.text: Eigth color for example additions success messages trusted content

docfields.name: KColorScheme::ShadeRole
docfields.text: Color shades are used to draw elements such as frames and bevels They are neither foreground nor background colors Text should not be painted over a shade and shades should not be used to draw text

docfields.name: KColorScheme::LightShade
docfields.text: The light color is lighter than dark() or shadow() and contrasts with the base color

docfields.name: KColorScheme::MidlightShade
docfields.text: The midlight color is in between base() and light()

docfields.name: KColorScheme::MidShade
docfields.text: The mid color is in between base() and dark()

docfields.name: KColorScheme::DarkShade
docfields.text: The dark color is in between mid() and shadow()

docfields.name: KColorScheme::ShadowShade
docfields.text: The shadow color is darker than light() or midlight() and contrasts the base color

docfields.name: KColorScheme::KColorScheme
docfields.text: KColorScheme provides direct access to the color scheme for users that deal directly with widget states Unless you are a low-level user or have a legitimate reason to only care about a fixed limited number of states e.g windows that cannot be inactive consider using a KStatefulBrush instead

docfields.name: KColorScheme::shade
docfields.text: Shades are chosen such that all shades would contrast with the base color This means that if base is very dark the dark shades will be lighter than the base color with midlight() shadow() Conversely if the base color is very light the light shades will be darker than the base color with light() mid()

docfields.name: KColorScheme::adjustBackground
docfields.text: Using this method is safer than replacing individual states as it insulates you against changes in QPalette::ColorGroup Although it is possible to replace a foreground color using this method it s bad usability to do so Just say

docfields.name: KColorScheme::adjustForeground
docfields.text: Using this method is safer than replacing individual states as it insulates you against changes in QPalette::ColorGroup Although it is possible to replace a background color using this method it s bad usability to do so Just say

docfields.name: KColorScheme::contrast
docfields.text: the contrast between 0 for minimum and 10 for maximum contrast

docfields.name: KColorScheme::contrastF
docfields.text: config pointer to the config from which to read the contrast setting the default is to use KSharedConfig::openConfig() the contrast between 0.0 for minimum and 1.0 for maximum contrast

docfields.name: KColorScheme::createApplicationPalette
docfields.text: config KConfig from which to load the colors the QPalette 5.0

docfields.name: KColorScheme::shade
docfields.text: Shades are chosen such that all shades would contrast with the base color This means that if base is very dark the dark shades will be lighter than the base color with midlight() shadow() Conversely if the base color is very light the light shades will be darker than the base color with light() mid()

docfields.name: KColorScheme::shade
docfields.text: contrast Amount roughly specifying the contrast by which to adjust the base color between and 1.0 values between 0.0 and 1.0 correspond to the value from KColorScheme::contrastF chromaAdjust optional Amount by which to adjust the chroma of the shade 1.0 means no adjustment Shades are chosen such that all shades would contrast with the base color This means that if base is very dark the dark shades will be lighter than the base color with midlight() shadow() Conversely if the base color is very light the light shades will be darker than the base color with light() mid() KColorUtils::shade

docfields.name: KColorSchemeManager
docfields.text: This is useful for applications which want to provide a selection of custom color schemes to their user For example it is very common for photo and painting applications to use a dark color scheme even if the default is a light scheme The KColorSchemeManager provides access to a QAbstractItemModel which holds all the available schemes A possible usage looks like the following In addition the KColorSchemeManager also provides the possibility to create a KActionMenu populated with all the available color schemes in an action group If one of the actions is selected the scheme is applied instantly 5.0

docfields.name: KColorSchemeManager::activateScheme
docfields.text: Installs the KColorScheme as the QApplication s QPalette index The index for the KColorScheme to activate The index must reference the QAbstractItemModel provided by model()

docfields.name: KColorSchemeManager::createSchemeSelectionMenu
docfields.text: All actions are in an action group and when one of the actions is triggered the scheme referenced by this action is activated The color scheme with the same name as selectedSchemeName will be checked If none of the available color schemes has the same name no action will be checked The KActionMenu will not be updated in case the installed color schemes change It s the task of the user of the KActionMenu to monitor for changes if required icon The icon to use for the KActionMenu text The text to use for the KActionMenu selectedSchemeName The name of the color scheme to select parent The parent of the KActionMenu KActionMenu populated with all available color schemes activateScheme

docfields.name: KColorSchemeManager::indexForScheme
docfields.text: If no such scheme exists an invalid index is returned model

docfields.name: KColorSchemeManager::model
docfields.text: The model provides the name of the scheme in Qt::DisplayRole a preview in Qt::DelegateRole and the full path to the scheme file in Qt::UserRole Model of all available color schemes

docfields.name: KConfigDialog
docfields.text: The KConfigDialog class provides an easy and uniform means of displaying a settings dialog using KPageDialog KConfigDialogManager and a KConfigSkeleton derived settings class KConfigDialog handles the enabling and disabling of buttons creation of the dialog and deletion of the widgets Because of KConfigDialogManager this class also manages restoring the settings reseting them to the default values and saving them This requires that the names of the widgets corresponding to configuration entries have to have the same name plus an additional prefix For example the widget named would be associated with the configuration entry Here is an example usage of KConfigDialog Other than the above code each class that has settings in the dialog should have a loadSettings() type slot to read settings and perform any necessary changes For dialog appearance options like buttons default button please see KPageDialog KConfigSkeleton Waldo Bastian

docfields.name: KConfigDialog::settingsChanged
docfields.text: dialogName the name of the dialog

docfields.name: KConfigDialog::KConfigDialog
docfields.text: parent The parent of this object Even though the class deletes itself the parent should be set so the dialog can be centered with the application on the screen name The name of this object The name is used in determining if there can be more than one dialog at a time Use names such as or and not just in applications where there is more than one dialog config Config object containing settings

docfields.name: KConfigDialog::~KConfigDialog
docfields.text: Deletes private class exists()

docfields.name: KConfigDialog::addPage
docfields.text: When an application is done adding pages show() should be called to display the dialog page Pointer to the page that is to be added to the dialog This object is reparented itemName Name of the page pixmapName Name of the icon that should be used if needed when displaying the page The string may either be the name of a themed icon e.g which the internal icon loader will be used to retrieve or an absolute path to the pixmap on disk header Header text use in the list modes Ignored in Tabbed mode If empty the itemName text is used when needed manage Whether KConfigDialogManager should manage the page or not The KPageWidgetItem associated with the page

docfields.name: KConfigDialog::addPage
docfields.text: This is useful for dialogs that contain settings spread over more than one configuration file and thus have/need more than one KConfigSkeleton When an application is done adding pages show() should be called to display the dialog page Pointer to the page that is to be added to the dialog This object is reparented config Config object containing corresponding settings itemName Name of the page pixmapName Name of the icon that should be used if needed when displaying the page The string may either be the name of a themed icon e.g which the internal icon loader will be used to retrieve or an absolute path to the pixmap on disk header Header text use in the list modes Ignored in Tabbed mode If empty the itemName text is used when needed The KPageWidgetItem associated with the page

docfields.name: KConfigDialog::exists
docfields.text: showDialog() name Dialog name to look for Pointer to widget or NULL if it does not exist

docfields.name: KConfigDialog::showDialog
docfields.text: exists() name The name of the dialog to show True if the dialog name exists and was shown

docfields.name: KConfigDialog::setHelp
docfields.text: The HTML file will be found using the X-DocPath entry in the application s desktop file It can be either a relative path or a website URL anchor This has to be a defined anchor in your docbook sources or website If empty the main index is loaded appname This allows you to specify the desktop file to get the help path from If empty the QCoreApplication::applicationName() is used

docfields.name: KConfigDialog::settingsChangedSlot
docfields.text: Emit the signal with the dialogs name Connect to this slot if there are widgets not managed by KConfig 4.3

docfields.name: KConfigDialog::updateButtons
docfields.text: Connect to this slot if you implement your own hasChanged() or isDefault() methods for widgets not managed by KConfig 4.3

docfields.name: KConfigDialog::updateSettings
docfields.text: Virtual function for custom additions Example use User clicks Ok or Apply button in a configure dialog

docfields.name: KConfigDialog::updateWidgets
docfields.text: Virtual function for custom additions Example use Initialisation of dialog Example use User clicks Reset button in a configure dialog

docfields.name: KConfigDialog::updateWidgetsDefault
docfields.text: Virtual function for custom additions Example use User clicks Defaults button in a configure dialog

docfields.name: KConfigDialog::hasChanged
docfields.text: Virtual function for custom additions

docfields.name: KConfigDialogManager
docfields.text: The KConfigDialogManager class provides a means of automatically retrieving saving and resetting basic settings It also can emit signals when settings have been changed settings were saved or modified the user changes a checkbox from on to off The names of the widgets to be managed have to correspond to the names of the configuration entries in the KConfigSkeleton object plus an additional prefix For example a widget named would be associated to the configuration entry New widgets can be added to the map using the static functions propertyMap() and changedMap() Note that you can t just add any class The class must have a matching Q_PROPERTY macro defined and a signal which emitted when the property changed Note by default the property which defined as is used For example note that KColorButton is already added and it doesn t need to manually added kcolorbutton.h defines the following property and signal To add KColorButton the following code would be inserted in the main If you want to use a widget s property that is not the USER property you can define which property to use in the widget s kcfg_property Alternatively you can set the kcfg_property using designer Benjamin C Meyer ben+kdelibs at meyerhome dot net Waldo Bastian

docfields.name: KConfigDialogManager::settingsChanged
docfields.text: This is only emitted by updateSettings() whenever one or more setting were changed and consequently saved

docfields.name: KConfigDialogManager::settingsChanged
docfields.text: widget The widget group pass in via addWidget() that contains the one or more modified setting settingsChanged()

docfields.name: KConfigDialogManager::widgetModified
docfields.text: Note that a settings can be modified several times and might go back to the original saved state hasChanged() will tell you if anything has actually changed from the saved values

docfields.name: KConfigDialogManager::updateSettings
docfields.text: Example use User clicks Ok or Apply button in a configure dialog

docfields.name: KConfigDialogManager::updateWidgets
docfields.text: Example use Initialisation of dialog Example use User clicks Reset button in a configure dialog

docfields.name: KConfigDialogManager::updateWidgetsDefault
docfields.text: Example use User clicks Defaults button in a configure dialog

docfields.name: KConfigDialogManager::KConfigDialogManager
docfields.text: parent Dialog widget to manage conf Object that contains settings

docfields.name: KConfigDialogManager::KConfigDialogManager
docfields.text: parent Dialog widget to manage conf Object that contains settings

docfields.name: KConfigDialogManager::addWidget
docfields.text: widget Additional widget to manage inlcuding all its children

docfields.name: KConfigDialogManager::getCustomProperty
docfields.text: Like a widget can use a property other than the USER property 4.3

docfields.name: KConfigDialogManager::init
docfields.text: trackChanges If any changes by the widgets should be tracked set true This causes the emitting the modified() signal when something changes TODO bool True if any setting was changed from the default

docfields.name: KConfigDialogManager::parseChildren
docfields.text: Goes through the children of widget and if any are known and not being ignored stores them in currentGroup Also checks if the widget should be disabled because it is set immutable widget Parent of the children to look at trackChanges If true then tracks any changes to the children of widget that are known bool If a widget was set to something other than its default

docfields.name: KLanguageButton
docfields.text: Languages are identified by their ISO 639-1 codes e.g en pt_BR KDE Language Selection Widget Hans Petter Bieker Martijn Klingens David Jarvie

docfields.name: KLanguageButton::activated
docfields.text: languageCode code of the activated language

docfields.name: KLanguageButton::highlighted
docfields.text: languageCode code of the highlighted language

docfields.name: KLanguageButton::KLanguageButton
docfields.text: parent the parent of the button

docfields.name: KLanguageButton::KLanguageButton
docfields.text: text the text of the button parent the parent of the button

docfields.name: KLanguageButton::contains
docfields.text: languageCode the language s code true if in the list

docfields.name: KLanguageButton::current
docfields.text: the current item s language code

docfields.name: KLanguageButton::insertLanguage
docfields.text: Normally the display name of the language is obtained automatically but if either the language code does not exist or there are special display requirements the name of the language can be specified in name languageCode the code for the language name language name If empty the name is obtained automatically index the insertion position or to insert in alphabetical order

docfields.name: KLanguageButton::insertSeparator
docfields.text: A negative index will append the item index the insertion position

docfields.name: KLanguageButton::loadAllLanguages
docfields.text: The current language in the list is set to the default language for the current locale as modified by setLocale()

docfields.name: KLanguageButton::setCurrentItem
docfields.text: languageCode the language s code

docfields.name: KLanguageButton::setLocale
docfields.text: By default QLocale::system() name() is used locale locale to use

docfields.name: KLanguageButton::setText
docfields.text: text button text

docfields.name: KLanguageButton::showLanguageCodes
docfields.text: Calling this method does not affect any previously inserted language texts so it should normally be called before populating the list show true to show codes false to hide codes

docfields.name: KPasteTextAction
docfields.text: It s useful for text handling applications as when plugged into a toolbar it provides a menu with the clipboard history if klipper is running If klipper is not running the menu has only one item the current clipboard content

docfields.name: KPasteTextAction::KPasteTextAction
docfields.text: parent The parent of this action

docfields.name: KPasteTextAction::KPasteTextAction
docfields.text: Option creates a shortcut with key O This is the most common KAction used when you do not have a corresponding icon note that it won t appear in the current version of the dialog because an action needs an icon to be plugged in a toolbar text The text that will be displayed parent The parent of this action

docfields.name: KPasteTextAction::KPasteTextAction
docfields.text: Option creates a shortcut with key O This is the other common KAction used Use it when you do have a corresponding icon icon The icon to display text The text that will be displayed parent The parent of this action

docfields.name: KPasteTextAction::setMixedMode
docfields.text: mode If false and the clipboard contains a non-text object the popup menu with the clipboard history will appear immediately as the user clicks the toolbar action if true the action works like the standard paste action even if the current clipboard object is not text Default value is true

docfields.name: KRecentFilesAction
docfields.text: This class is an action to handle a recent files submenu The best way to create the action is to use KStandardAction::openRecent Then you simply need to call loadEntries on startup saveEntries on shutdown addURL when your application loads/saves a file Michael Koch

docfields.name: KRecentFilesAction::recentListCleared
docfields.text: So when user store url in specific config file it can saveEntry 4.3

docfields.name: KRecentFilesAction::urlSelected
docfields.text: url The URL thats the user selected

docfields.name: KRecentFilesAction::clear
docfields.text: Note that there is also an action shown to the user for clearing the list

docfields.name: KRecentFilesAction::KRecentFilesAction
docfields.text: parent The parent of this action

docfields.name: KRecentFilesAction::KRecentFilesAction
docfields.text: Option creates a shortcut with key O This is the most common KAction used when you do not have a corresponding icon note that it won t appear in the current version of the dialog because an action needs an icon to be plugged in a toolbar text The text that will be displayed parent The parent of this action

docfields.name: KRecentFilesAction::KRecentFilesAction
docfields.text: Option creates a shortcut with key O This is the other common KAction used Use it when you do have a corresponding icon icon The icon to display text The text that will be displayed parent The parent of this action

docfields.name: KRecentFilesAction::addAction
docfields.text: Do not use addAction(QAction*) as no url will be associated and consequently urlSelected() will not be emitted when action is selected

docfields.name: KRecentFilesAction::addUrl
docfields.text: url The URL of the file name The user visible pretty name that appears before the URL Create a deep copy here because if _url is the parameter from urlSelected() signal we will delete it in the removeAction() call below but access it again in the addAction call crash

docfields.name: KRecentFilesAction::loadEntries
docfields.text: You can provide the name of the group used to load the entries If the groupname is empty entries are loaded from a group called RecentFiles Local file entries that do not exist anymore are not restored

docfields.name: KRecentFilesAction::removeUrl
docfields.text: url The URL of the file

docfields.name: KRecentFilesAction::saveEntries
docfields.text: You can provide the name of the group used to load the entries If the groupname is empty entries are saved to a group called RecentFiles

docfields.name: KRecentFilesAction::setMaxItems
docfields.text: The default for this value is 10 set in the constructor If this value is lesser than the number of items currently in the recent files list the last items are deleted until the number of items are equal to the new maximum

docfields.name: KStatefulBrush
docfields.text: KStatefulBrush provides an easy and safe way to store a color for use in a user interface It is both in that it will make it easy to deal with widget states in a correct manner and that it insulates you against changes in QPalette::ColorGroup Basically a stateful brush is used to cache a particular from the KDE system palette usually one which does not live in QPalette When you are ready to draw using the brush you use the current state to retrieve the appropriate brush Stateful brushes can also be used to apply state effects to arbitrary brushes for example when working with a application specific user-defined color palette As of Qt 4.3 QPalette::ColorGroup is missing a state for disabled widgets in an inactive window Hopefully Trolltech will fix this bug at which point KColorScheme and KStatefulBrush will be updated to recognize the new state Using KStatefulBrush will allow your application to inherit these changes without even recompiling

docfields.name: KStatefulBrush::KStatefulBrush
docfields.text: For such an instance all overloads of KStatefulBrush::brush will return a default brush i.e QBrush()

docfields.name: KStatefulBrush::KStatefulBrush
docfields.text: The various states are determined from the base QBrush which fills in the Active state according to the same rules used to build stateful color schemes from the system color scheme The state effects from the given KConfig are used if null the system state effects are used

docfields.name: KStatefulBrush::KStatefulBrush
docfields.text: The various states are determined from the base QBrush which fills in the Active state according to the same rules used to build stateful color schemes from the system color scheme The state effects from the given KConfig are used if null the system state effects are used background The background brush or color corresponding to the KColorScheme::NormalBackground role and QPalette::Active state for this foreground/decoration color

docfields.name: KStatefulBrush::brush
docfields.text: This is used when you know explicitly what state is wanted Otherwise one of overloads is often more convenient

docfields.name: KStatefulBrush::brush
docfields.text: Use when your painting code has easy access to the QPalette that it is supposed to be using The state used in this instance is the currentColorGroup of the palette

docfields.name: KStatefulBrush::brush
docfields.text: Use when you have a pointer to the widget that you are painting The state used is the current state of the widget If you pass an invalid widget you will get a default brush i.e QBrush()

docfields.name: KTipDatabase
docfields.text: This class provides convenient access to a database containing tips of the day The database is stored in a XML file and parsed when a KTipDatabase object is created Once the file is read in you can access the tips to display them in the tip of the day dialog The state of the tipdialog is saved to the applications s config file in the group with a bool entry Check this value if you want to allow the user to enable/disable the tipdialog in the application s configuration dialog KDE Tip-of-the-Day Dialog Matthias Hoelzer-Kluepfel

docfields.name: KTipDatabase::KTipDatabase
docfields.text: If no name is given a file called application-name/tips will be loaded tipFile The absolute path to the tips file

docfields.name: KTipDatabase::KTipDatabase
docfields.text: This constructor essentially behaves like the one above It returns when tipFiles is empty tipFiles A list of absolute paths to the tips file

docfields.name: KTipDialog
docfields.text: This dialog class presents a tip-of-the-day The tips will be looked up for translation using gettext with KLocalizedString::applicationDomain() as domain Matthias Hoelzer-Kluepfel

docfields.name: KTipDialog::KTipDialog
docfields.text: database TipDatabase that should be used by the TipDialog The KTipDialog will take ownership of the database including deleting it parent Parent widget of TipDialog Parent is 0L when TipDialog is used as a mainWidget This should be the case only in ktip so let s use the ktip layout

docfields.name: KTipDialog::setShowOnStart
docfields.text: Normally the user can disable the display of the tip in the dialog This is just a way to change this setting from outside

docfields.name: KTipDialog::showMultiTip
docfields.text: This method behaves essentially as the one above but expects a list of tips parent Parent widget of TipDialog tipFiles A List of tip files Each has be relative to the GenericDataLocation resource of QStandardPaths force If true the dialog is show even when the users disabled it

docfields.name: KTipDialog::showTip
docfields.text: This static method is all that is needed to add a tip-of-the-day dialog to an application It will pop up the dialog unless the user has asked that the dialog does not pop up on startup Note that you probably want an item in the help menu calling this method with force true parent Parent widget of TipDialog tipFile The name of the tip file It has be relative to the GenericDataLocation resource of QStandardPaths force If true the dialog is show even when the users disabled it

docfields.name: KTipDialog::showTip
docfields.text: use the one with a parent window as parameter instead of this one or you will get focus problems This methods calls showTip() with the applications main window as parent

docfields.name: KTipDialog::eventFilter
docfields.text: If the user presses Return or Space we close the dialog as if the default button was pressed even if the QTextBrowser has the keyboard focus This could have the bad side-effect that the user cannot use the keyboard to open urls in the QTextBrowser so we just let it handle the key event additionally Antonio

docfields.name: KStandardAction
docfields.text: These actions should be used instead of hardcoding menubar and toolbar items Using these actions helps your application easily conform to the KDE UI Style Guide All of the documentation for QAction holds for KStandardAction also When in doubt on how things work check the QAction documention first Please note that calling any of these methods automatically adds the action to the actionCollection() of the QObject given by the parent parameter Simple Example In general using standard actions should be a drop in replacement for regular actions For example if you previously had You could drop that and replace it with Non-standard Usages It is possible to use the standard actions in various non-recommended ways Say for instance you wanted to have a standard action with the associated correct text and icon and accelerator etc but you didn t want it to go in the standard place this is not recommended by the way One way to do this is to simply not use the XML UI framework and plug it into wherever you want If you do want to use the XML UI framework good! then it is still possible Basically the XML building code matches names in the XML code with the internal names of the actions You can find out the internal names of each of the standard actions by using the name method like so KStandardAction::name(KStandardAction::Cut) would return edit_cut The XML building code will match edit_cut to the attribute in the global XML file and place your action there However you can change the internal name In this example just do something like Now in your local XML resource file e.g yourappui.rc simply put my_cut where you want it to go Another non-standard usage concerns getting a pointer to an existing action if say you want to enable or disable the action You could do it the recommended way and just grab a pointer when you instantiate it as in the openNew example above or you could do it the hard way Another non-standard usage concerns instantiating the action in the first place Usually you would use the member functions as shown above e.g KStandardAction::cut(this, SLOT, parent) You may however do this using the enums provided This author can t think of a reason why you would want to but hey if you do here s how Kurt Granroth

docfields.name: KStandardAction::clear
docfields.text: Calls clear() on the widget with the current focus Note that for some widgets this may not provide the intended behavior For example if you make use of the code above and a K3ListView has the focus clear() will clear all of the items in the list If this is not the intened behavior and you want to make use of this slot you can subclass K3ListView and reimplement this slot For example the following code would implement a K3ListView without this behavior

docfields.name: KStandardAction::copy
docfields.text: Calls copy() on the widget with the current focus

docfields.name: KStandardAction::create
docfields.text: if you use OpenRecent as id you should manually connect to the urlSelected(const QUrl &) signal of the returned KRecentFilesAction instead or use KStandardAction::openRecent(Receiver *, Func) create(StandardAction, const QObject *, const char *, QObject *) 5.23

docfields.name: KStandardAction::create
docfields.text: The signal that is connected to slot is triggered(bool) except for the case of OpenRecent standard action which uses the urlSelected(const QUrl &) signal of KRecentFilesAction id The StandardAction identifier to create a QAction for recvr The QObject to receive the signal or 0 if no notification is needed slot The slot to connect the signal to remember to use the SLOT() macro parent The QObject that should own the created QAction or 0 if no parent will own the QAction returned ensure you delete it manually in this case

docfields.name: KStandardAction::cut
docfields.text: Calls cut() on the widget with the current focus

docfields.text: KConfigWidgets Widgets for configuration dialogs Introduction KConfigWidgets provides easy-to-use classes to create configuration dialogs as well as a set of widgets which uses KConfig to store their settings
